source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: Gig Work Is Risky for Apps, Too
description: New and proposed laws and regulatory challenges threaten the business model of apps like Uber and Handy.
content: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Casselman, Patricia Cohen, Conor Dougherty and Nelson D. Schwartz
title: A Lifeline to the Jobless Has Problems With Fraud, and With Math
description: An emergency federal program faces growing issues with spurious claims, and the flood of applicants may have led to overcounting the unemployed.
content: Two weeks ago, shortly after she advertised an apartment for rent in the Bay Area, Barbara Lamb found five envelopes from the state’s unemployment office in the building’s communal mail slot. They kept coming, day after day, until a stack of more than 30 piled up, bulging with notices of benefit approvals, questionnaires about job status — and debit cards with money.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green, Maya Phillips, Laura Collins-Hughes, Elisabeth Vincentelli and Alexis Soloski
title: How to Birth a New American Theater
description: Six months dark. Thousands of artists out of work. Could this disaster have a surprise ending? Five critics on what must change, onstage and off.
content: When New York City shut down on March 12, its theaters were preparing for a busy spring season: big names on Broadway, Tony Awards mania, millions of dollars in sales and of course a smattering of thoughtful, important plays on smaller stages.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: Dated 1920, a Postcard Finally Gets Delivered
description: Brittany Keech does not know how a message from 100 years ago landed in her mailbox. Now she’s trying to find relatives of the intended recipient.
content: The postcard, faded and weathered, has a postmark dated Oct. 29, 1920, and a green stamp of George Washington, priced 1 cent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Not on Time, but That’s OK
description: Caitlin Reid and Erik Agard finally arrive to open our solving weekend.
content: FRIDAY PUZZLE — Well, this puzzle by Caitlin Reid and Erik Agard was very satisfying.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Rasgon and Mohammed Najib
title: Palestinians Rejected Tax Money to Slap Israel. It’s Not Israel That’s Hurting.
description: Palestinian families are suffering intensely as their government’s tax protest continues, even though the cause — Israel’s push to annex the West Bank — has been suspended.
content: RAMALLAH, West Bank — Furious that Israel was about to annex large swaths of the West Bank, the Palestinian Authority president, Mahmoud Abbas, took the painful step in June of refusing to accept taxes collected by Israel that account for more than 60 percent of the authority’s budget.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: Dominic Thiem and Alexander Zverev Give U.S. Open a New Look for Final
description: For the first time in four years, a Grand Slam men’s singles tournament will end without Roger Federer, Rafael Nadal or Novak Djokovic as the champion.
content: Dominic Thiem has certainly paid his dues in the long-running era of the Big Three. And on Sunday, with Novak Djokovic, Rafael Nadal and Roger Federer all out of the picture, Thiem will get his next and best chance to win his first Grand Slam singles title.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jillian Rayfield
title: 11 of Our Best Weekend Reads
description: Wildfires. Jacob Blake. Diana Rigg. London’s bridges. Tilda Swinton. And more.
content: Welcome to the weekend. As we start to get into fall, you may feel like the pandemic and the nonstop news cycle have killed the concept of the weekend for you. You’re not alone: “It feels like perpetual Thursday,” one woman said. If it does seem like you’re living in the movie “Groundhog Day,” there are still ways to enjoy the time off you do have, even if it’s just by making this cheesy toast. Whatever you do, be sure to make time for some great journalism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kurt Andersen
title: How Liberals Opened the Door to Libertarian Economics
description: Milton Friedman’s free-market ideas found favor in a free-love era and helped redirect the country toward the right. The aftershocks of his radical arguments are still being felt today.
content: On September 13th, 1970, the New York Times Magazine published an essay by Milton Friedman entitled “The Social Responsibility of Business Is to Increase Its Profits,” which turned out to be one of the most influential economic arguments of the century.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rosalie R. Radomsky
title: After the After-Parties, Act 1, Scene 1
description: Shauna Perlman and Julie Oh went from party to party after the Tony Awards ceremony in 2014, and then gingerly entered into a relationship.
content: Shauna Lauren Perlman and Julie Sujin Oh were on familiar turf as they went from party to party after the 2014 Tony Awards ceremony at Radio City Music Hall in Manhattan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: Saying Goodbye to Australia
description: With an upcoming departure from Sydney, one Australian reporter reflects on the experience of home and the country’s culture of simple pleasures.
content: It was the slow pace that struck me most when I returned to my hometown, Sydney, three years ago from Washington, D.C.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Asthaa Chaturvedi
title: Investigating the Killing of Breonna Taylor
description: Piecing together new details of her life and death through audio.
content: Listen to ‘The Killing of Breonna Taylor’: Part 1 and Part 2
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei
title: Ex-Felons in Florida Must Pay Fines Before Voting, Appeals Court Rules
description: In a reversal, a court said Floridians who had completed sentences for felonies must pay fines and fees before voting. The State Constitution was amended in 2018 to restore their rights.
content: MIAMI — Four months after a federal judge ruled that it was akin to an unconstitutional poll tax for Florida to require that people with serious criminal convictions pay court fines and fees before they can register to vote, an appeals court narrowly overturned that decision on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stefanos Chen
title: In New Development, Buyers Favor the Boroughs
description: Yes, some buyers are leaving Manhattan. But others are doubling down on Brooklyn and Queens.
content: When it comes to new development, buyers who are choosing to stay in New York — and have the means to stay — are choosing Brooklyn and Queens.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Politi and Ernesto Londoño
title: 2 Young Girls Killed and Former V.P. Missing in Paraguay Guerrilla Conflict
description: A military operation targeting a small insurgent group has led to accusations of a government cover-up in the deaths of two young girls from Argentina.
content: BUENOS AIRES — Paraguay’s president hailed a raid last week on a guerrilla camp as a successful operation that killed two militants.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman
title: In New York, rivals cross paths, and bump elbows.
description: Vice President Mike Pence traded an elbow bump with the Democratic nominee for president, Joseph R. Biden Jr., Friday morning when the two attended a ceremony in Lower Manhattan marking the Sept. 11 attacks.
content: Vice President Mike Pence traded an elbow bump with the Democratic nominee for president, Joseph R. Biden Jr., Friday morning when the two attended a ceremony in Lower Manhattan marking the Sept. 11 attacks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: James Jackson, Who Changed the Study of Black America, Dies at 76
description: Rather than focus on interracial comparisons, his National Survey of Black Americans explored the complexities within the Black population.
content: James S. Jackson, who changed the way scholars examined Black life in the United States, leading to new insights on health, social support systems and more, when he founded the Program for Research on Black Americans at the University of Michigan in 1976, died on Sept. 1 at his home in Ann Arbor, Mich. He was 76.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: Executives to Step Down After Rio Tinto Destroys Sacred Australian Sites
description: The mining giant’s chief executive was among those pushed out after shareholders revolted over the destruction of ancient Indigenous sites in Western Australia.
content: DARWIN, Australia — The caves, set deep in a desert gorge, had yielded a treasure trove of artifacts tracing Aboriginal people’s long history in Australia: a 28,000-year-old kangaroo bone sharpened into a blade; a 4,000-year-old plait of human hair believed to have been worn as a belt.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Eligon
title: Chiefs Fans, Used to Chops and Cheers, React to N.F.L.’s New Climate
description: Kansas City’s fans are among the loudest in pro football. But the celebratory start to their season silenced game rituals and drew mixed opinions on players’ protests of racial injustice.
content: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — Kent Gaines stepped out of his car on Thursday evening, a red mask swinging from his finger, and took in the scene around him in the parking lot of Arrowhead Stadium. It was just before the Kansas City Chiefs and the Houston Texans kicked off to start an N.F.L. season unlike any he had ever experienced as a season-ticket holder.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Healy and Mike Baker
title: In Oregon, a Year of Political Tumult Extends to Devastating Wildfires
description: A tumultuous summer of protests has become a complication in the wildfires raging around Portland.
content: MOLALLA, Ore. — Ralph Mitchell’s neighbors were fleeing. Ash rained from the sky. And outside Mr. Mitchell’s natural-medicine business, a police cruiser announced on loudspeaker: “This has been declared a life-threatening fire emergency. You need to evacuate the city.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mychal Denzel Smith
title: A Biden Win Won’t Cure My Trump-Era Depression
description: I find hope and relief from my misery in things that have nothing to do with the election.
content: When I was 12 years old, my cousin was killed. I started having trouble sleeping.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Behind the Cover: Education
description: A look at education in America as many students go back to school amid the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Brantley
title: Review: A Family Gropes for Words in ‘Incidental Moments’
description: Richard Nelson’s profound conclusion to his Zoom-format trilogy about the Apple siblings examines the perils of conversation in 2020.
content: There is so much they all want — no need — to say. They have always been a family for whom conversation is as essential as oxygen, a means of defining and confirming their own identities in relation to one another and to the wide, heaving world that keeps shifting beyond and beneath them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Schuessler and Scott Heller
title: 20 Theater Figures on How to ‘Revolutionize’ Their World
description: End unpaid internships. Set term limits for leaders. Get real about inclusion. Take performances to the streets. Say yes to joy, and no to couch plays.
content: Whoopi Goldberg had a suggestion: Stop calling Broadway “The Great White Way,” she proposed on “The View” in June, and nickname it “The Great Bright Way” instead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: Democrats Gained These Voters in 2018, and Biden Needs to Keep Them Now
description: An authoritative new study on 2018 midterm voters shows how despite his strong position, Joe Biden is lagging behind the rates at which some key demographics broke for the Democrats two years ago.
content: Welcome to Poll Watch, our weekly look at polling data and survey research on the candidates, voters and issues that will shape the 2020 election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Weed
title: How to Network From Home
description: While team meetings and industry conventions have moved online, the pandemic has opened as many doors as it has closed.
content: Maybe you were never comfortable networking at the office or striking up a conversation over a boxed lunch at a convention, but after half a year working inside your own four walls, oh, the chance to meet new people!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Greg Weiner
title: The Towering Lies of President Trump
description: It’s simple. Everything that benefits Mr. Trump is true and everything that inconveniences him is false.
content: President Trump’s taped admission to Bob Woodward that he deliberately misled Americans about the danger of the coronavirus makes him morally culpable in the ensuing tragedy. But Mr. Trump actually forfeited the battle against the pandemic long before it erupted in Wuhan, China, in the first place. His tragic failures are a result of a systematic skepticism — an opportunistic cynicism — whose orienting principle is that everything that benefits Mr. Trump is true and everything that inconveniences him is false.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noor Brara
title: Finding a Place for Third-Culture Kids in the Culture
description: In his new HBO series, the filmmaker Luca Guadagnino revisits a timeless yet timely question: What does it mean to be from everywhere and nowhere at once?
content: On a blanched, sun-baked afternoon, two teenagers, a boy and a girl, wander into a grocery store to pick up lunch. Fraser is a recent transplant from New York, and Britney a new friend who has lived her life evenly between South Korea, Germany and Italy, though you’d never know it by her American drawl or the pop music she blares through her headphones. To the viewer, the scene presents like quotidian life in the United States — but for the fact that it takes place in Veneto, Italy, on a military base where families work and attend school, their children running off every evening to dance and drink by the cerulean sea alongside their friends from town with whom they scheme and share secrets, whispered in fluent Italian. In a few years, many of them will ready themselves for a move — to another home on another military base in another country, with a supermarket configured to look exactly like this one. “They look the same so you don’t feel lost,” Britney tells Fraser. “Do you ever feel lost?” he asks. She shrugs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Felicia Campbell, Professor Who Studied Gambling and Pop Culture, Dies at 89
description: Ms. Campbell was the longest-serving professor at the University of Nevada, Las Vegas. She died of complications of the novel coronavirus.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brennan Carley
title: Back to School With Tan France
description: The “Queer Eye” star has a lot to teach us about dressing.
content: Three years ago at an Embassy Suites in Glendale, Calif., Antoni Porowski spotted his soon-to-be co-star Tan France in the hotel’s gym. Mr. France was wearing tailored gym shorts and a crisp Nike shirt tucked neatly into his waistband. His hair was perfectly coifed and he was smiling as he StairMastered without breaking a sweat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Fauci Says It Could Be a Year Before Theater Without Masks Feels Normal
description: Dr. Anthony Fauci said a vaccine would need to exist for nearly a year before people might feel comfortable returning to theaters unmasked, which he said would likely be mid- to late 2021.
content: As theaters look to see how they might reopen with safety accommodations including mask use, Dr. Anthony Fauci says it will likely be more than a year before people feel comfortable returning to theaters without masks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold
title: New York City Marks 9/11 at a Time of Harrowing Loss
description: As they memorialize a past tragedy, New Yorkers face another profound and deadly crisis that is not yet over.
content: The mourners entering the plaza wore face masks, and the teary, intimate hugs of years past were replaced by awkwardly choreographed fist bumps. When the bells tolled at 8:46 a.m., marking the moment the first jet smashed into the north tower 19 years ago, those gathered stood at somber attention, trying to draw comfort from neighbors required to stand six feet apart.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson
title: N.F.L. Season Kicks Off With Players’ Protesting Racism
description: After an off-season of social turmoil, the Houston Texans chose not to be on the field for the playing of “Lift Every Voice and Sing” and “The Star-Spangled Banner” before the league’s season opener in Kansas City, Mo.
content: After an off-season of social and political turmoil, N.F.L. players made it clear on the night of the season opener that they will continue to shine a light on social injustice and police brutality against African Americans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Adam Goldman
title: Whistle-Blower’s Complaint Ignites a Smoldering Homeland Security Agency
description: The agency created to share information across governments is accused of distorting its intelligence to play down the threats posed by Russia and white supremacists.
content: WASHINGTON — Well before his move to the Department of Homeland Security, Brian Murphy had become known as an ambitious counterterrorism investigator at the F.B.I., determined and relentless. At times, though, colleagues chafed at what some saw as an overzealous disregard for bureaucratic rules.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farah Stockman
title: What I Learned From a List of Trump Accomplishments
description: Facts are vital. But they are not sufficient.
content: Don’t ask me why, but I’ve spent the past week fact-checking a list of Donald Trump’s accomplishments, as compiled by one of his loyal supporters. OK, if you must know: A friend asked me to because she didn’t believe this list could be true, and she was upset that someone she respected had posted it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Lee Myers and Sameer Yasir
title: China and India Pledge to Ease Tensions After Border Clashes
description: The foreign ministers of the two countries issued a five-point statement aimed at ending a simmering confrontation. A previous pledge was followed by the deadliest clash in decades.
content: China and India have once again pledged to defuse tensions along their contested Himalayan border, days after officials in both countries accused the other of firing shots in the region for the first time in decades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jared Wood
title: What I Learned From My Instagram Crush
description: Can anything good come from obsessing over a South Korean bodybuilder on social media?
content: It took two hours and three buses to reach his gym. I was working a split shift at an English language academy in Seoul, leaving me a gap of five hours for taking a nap or traveling to his gym, where, given the long commute, I would barely have enough time to break a sweat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marian Bull
title: A Jewelry Designer’s Prized Family Vegetable Recipe
description: When Beth Bugdaycay serves her favorite green beans, she is not only feeding her own family but paying tribute to her husband’s Turkish heritage.
content: When, at 22, the jewelry designer Beth Bugdaycay traveled to Istanbul to meet her new mother-in-law, she arrived with a request: that her husband’s mother teach her a few family dishes. “I think sharing a family recipe with another person is very personal,” says Beth, now 47, who co-founded the jewelry company Foundrae with her husband, Murat, in 2015, and lives with him and their two children above their TriBeCa store. “Learning hers was a way to show that I respected her family and her culture, and that I was committed to keeping those traditions alive with her son in New York.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Schmitt
title: Russian Attack Jets Back Mercenaries Fighting in Libya
description: An American military official said the warplanes were conducting combat missions in support of Kremlin-backed private security forces, and extending Moscow’s influence in Africa.
content: WASHINGTON — More than a dozen attack jets that Russia sent to Libya this year are conducting ground strikes and other combat missions in support of Russian mercenaries fighting alongside a beleaguered commander in his campaign to oust the government from Tripoli, the capital, a top American military official said on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Timothy Egan
title: I’ve Never Seen the American West in Such Deep Distress
description: We’re choking on smoke and staring out at Martian-red skies in a world becoming uninhabitable.
content: The open road in the Big Empty part of the American West has always been therapeutic. Vacant skies, horizons that stretch to infinity, country without clutter. The soul needs to roam, too.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Hubler and Anemona Hartocollis
title: How Colleges Became the New Covid Hot Spots
description: Like meatpacking plants and nursing homes early in the pandemic, campuses across the country are experiencing outbreaks.
content: It began last month with a trickle of coronavirus infections as college students arrived for the fall semester. Soon that trickle became a stream, with campuses reporting dozens, and sometimes hundreds, of new cases each day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Weekend
description: Make Tejal Rao’s latest, a vegetarian kofta, inspired by one of her favorite grandfather’s specialties.
content: Good morning. Nineteen years ago today, I stared at the empty bluebird sky from a patch of grass next to a stretch of open, sparkly water, a week-old baby in a carrier beside me, grief everywhere in the sun, unsure of what we’d done, to bring a child into such a world. I sat that way a long time. Later I cooked as if it could do something, a roast chicken to feed a new family, a scent to counter smoke, a balm against reality’s angry rash. It did not help much, but it helped.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Ken Robinson, Who Preached Creativity in Teaching, Dies at 70
description: Dance, he said, is just as important as math. He was knighted for his work, and his TED Talk on schools and the arts was the most viewed of all time.
content: Ken Robinson, a dynamic, influential proponent of stimulating the creativity of students that has too often been squelched by schools in the service of conformity, died on Aug. 21 at his home in London. He was 70.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pranshu Verma and Kenneth P. Vogel
title: The U.S. imposed sanctions on a Ukrainian with ties to Russia, citing election interference.
description: The Trump administration imposed sanctions on a Ukrainian lawmaker Thursday for waging “a covert influence campaign” to undermine the presidential election after he disseminated information intended to hurt Joseph R. Biden Jr.
content: The Trump administration imposed sanctions on a Ukrainian lawmaker Thursday for waging “a covert influence campaign” to undermine the presidential election after he disseminated information intended to hurt Joseph R. Biden Jr.

author: By Deborah Tannen
title: How I Finally Got to Know My Father by Asking About His Past
description: Well into adulthood, I felt that I could never make up for the father-time I’d missed as a child. But it turned out that I could. And I did.
content: I adored my father. He’s the parent I felt an affinity with, the one I thought understood me. But when I was growing up in Brooklyn in the late ’40s and early ’50s, he was rarely home. He worked overtime as a cutter in the garment district, late into the evening during the week and all day Saturday. Most Sundays he was busy “being active,” as we called it, in New York’s Liberal Party, in recompense for which he was promised a political appointment that would allow him to escape the factory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariro Mzezewa
title: For Hotels, Cleaning Is Key. But Cleaners Say Their Jobs Are Under Assault.
description: The hotel industry says doing away with daily room cleanings keeps guests and staff safe. But housekeepers say it is a step toward cutting earnings and job security.
content: In the past four months, nearly every major hotel brand in the world has announced a cleaning program highlighting new disinfecting and sterilizing procedures. Many companies are consulting with medical organizations; some are using robots; all say they are cleaning more than ever before. Their messaging is clear: Hotels are very clean.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: Keep Track of the Tiny Details
description: They’ll unlock a cascade of memory in the future.
content: Welcome. I like to get up while it’s dark, before anyone else has begun to stir, walking through the apartment on tiptoe with the world on mute. I fix my coffee in the dark and wake up slowly. There are fewer variables, minimal stimuli. At 5 a.m., New York’s famed sleeplessness is repudiated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sui-Lee Wee
title: How China is using promises of a vaccine as a diplomatic carrot.
description: With pledges of a coronavirus vaccine, China is on a charm offensive to repair strained diplomatic ties and bolster engagement with other countries.
content: China is still most likely months away from mass producing a vaccine that is safe for public use. But the country is using the prospect of the drug’s discovery in a charm offensive aimed at repairing damaged ties and bringing friends closer in regions China deems vital to its interests.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vincent M. Mallozzi
title: At Home for All the Holidays
description: Damon Dickinson and Neil Alpert bonded over a love of travel, cooking, the television sitcom “Golden Girls,” and Christmas.
content: Despite the fact that Damon Dickinson and Neil Alpert are Jewish, the couple have celebrated Christmas with Mr. Dickinson’s family each of the last four years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg and Adam Pasick
title: A Favorite Teacher Lost
description: Educators’ deaths are part of an unabated pandemic.
content: Demetria Bannister, known as Demi, a 28-year-old third-grade teacher and choir director in Columbia, S.C., died of Covid-19 on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Tanis
title: Let the Flavors Do the Work
description: Farmers’ market produce is at its peak, and David Tanis thinks you should simply let it shine on its own in this dinner.
content: Here we are again at summer’s end, and, if ever there is a time of year to enjoy fresh produce in its glorious prime, it is now. Farmers’ markets are full of gorgeous summer fruits and vegetables — fragrant, ripe and sweet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Weinstein
title: Recipes for Right Now
description: These dishes embrace summer produce, and honor those fall cravings.
content: Hello and welcome to Five Weeknight Dishes. Celestially speaking, we are still in summer, but as soon as we pass Labor Day, I start thinking of roast chicken, squash and apple cakes. (This may have something to do with the fact that your hard-working NYT Cooking staff is currently preparing for Thanksgiving.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: How the Pandemic Has Changed Apartment Building Amenities
description: Copper door handles, sectional sofas instead of giant couches, and hospital-grade ventilation systems find their way into new buildings.
content: After the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, some landlords installed sturdy posts outside their buildings to guard against future strikes.

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: Larry Wilmore Doesn’t Miss Late Night, but He’s Back Anyway
description: Four years after the abrupt end of “The Nightly Show,” Wilmore has a new topical comedy series on Peacock.
content: Back when Larry Wilmore was about to introduce “The Nightly Show,” his short-lived late-night series on Comedy Central, he saw a tweet from an angry prospective viewer who wished failure on the host and his lousy show, which at that point had not yet aired a single episode.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: He Calls Baseball Games by Ear. Without Fans, His Job Is a Lot Harder.
description: Enrique Oliu, a blind radio broadcaster for the Tampa Bay Rays, relies on crowd noise and on-field sounds to do his job. This season, he’s had to adjust more than anyone.
content: The soundtrack of the 2020 baseball season, played amid a pandemic, is undoubtedly different. The pop of the catcher’s mitt, the thwack of the bat and the fervor from the dugouts sound louder without the buffer of tens of thousands of cheering fans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘High Schoolers Across the Country Are Seeking “Teenager Therapy’’’
description: In this lesson, students will learn about a podcast started by five teenagers from a bedroom that has become a lifeline for other kids. Then they will consider what kind of podcast they would want to create.

title: Bruce Springsteen’s Classic E Street Tune, and 11 More New Songs

title: Serena’s Rivals Are Emboldened. But She Still Has the Fire and the Game.
